Name: TellTheClass
Description: Teacher presents information directly to the entire class
explanation: When learners have developed intuitions about the concepts to be learned, it is effective to give a short lecture that clearly presents what these concepts.
sources: Sinha T. & Kapur M. (2021). When problem solving followed by instruction works: Evidence for productive failure. Review of Educational Research 91(5) 761-798.
llm_prompt: Make 2 slides that explain <task> to <age> year old learners. Each slide should have a clear title and 3-4 key points that are age-appropriate and easy to understand.

Name: DesirableDifficultyProblem
Description: Students work on challenging problems that enhance long-term retention
explanation: Failing to solve the problem nonetheless prepares learners to make sense of the following lecture by activating relevant prior knowledge and highlighting knowledge gaps.
sources: Sinha T. & Kapur M. (2021). When problem solving followed by instruction works: Evidence for productive failure. Review of Educational Research 91(5) 761-798.
llm_prompt: Create a challenge that is different from the main goal task but requires reasoning in a similar way for <age>-year old learners and last for <duration> minutes. It is fine if they don't find the right solution but they must be able to try a few things. Make it intriguing and thought-provoking.

Name: PracticeMemory
Description: Individual exercises focused on memorization and recall
explanation: Retrieval practice strengthens memory consolidation and improves long-term retention more effectively than passive review. The testing effect shows that repeated retrieval attempts create stronger memory traces.
sources: Roediger H.L. & Karpicke J.D. (2006). Test-enhanced learning: Taking memory tests improves long-term retention. Psychological Science 17(3) 249-255.
llm_prompt: Create memory practice exercises for <task> that will take <duration> minutes for <age>-year old learners. Include activities like flashcards, key term matching, or fill-in-the-blank questions that reinforce memorization and recall.

Name: PracticeApplication
Description: Students apply learned concepts to solve practical problems
explanation: Application practice helps transfer knowledge to new contexts and develops procedural fluency. Students learn to recognize when and how to apply concepts to real-world situations.
sources: Mayer R.E. (2002). Rote versus meaningful learning. Theory Into Practice 41(4) 226-232.
llm_prompt: Make exercises for <task> for <duration> minutes for <age> learners. Focus on practical application problems where students can use what they've learned in realistic scenarios. Include 3-5 progressively challenging problems.

Name: PracticeAnalyse
Description: Team-based analysis activities to break down and understand concepts
explanation: Collaborative analysis develops critical thinking and deeper conceptual understanding. Students learn to break down complex ideas into components and examine relationships between parts.
sources: Chi M.T.H. (2009). Active-constructive-interactive: A conceptual framework for differentiating learning activities. Topics in Cognitive Science 1(1) 73-105.
llm_prompt: Create a team-based analysis activity for <task> lasting <duration> minutes for <age>-year old learners. Students should work in small groups to break down concepts, identify patterns, and examine relationships. Provide a structured framework with guiding questions.

Name: PracticeEvaluate
Description: Collaborative evaluation of ideas solutions or arguments
explanation: Evaluative thinking engages higher-order cognitive processes and metacognition. Peer discussion during evaluation exposes students to diverse perspectives and improves judgment skills.
sources: King P.M. & Kitchener K.S. (1994). Developing reflective judgment: Understanding and promoting intellectual growth. Jossey-Bass.
llm_prompt: Design an evaluation activity for <task> for <age>-year old learners lasting <duration> minutes. Have teams assess different solutions, approaches, or arguments using clear criteria. Include a rubric or evaluation framework to guide their critical thinking.

Name: PracticeCreate
Description: Students create original work demonstrating mastery
explanation: Creation tasks require synthesis of multiple concepts and promote deep understanding. The generative learning effect shows that producing new content enhances retention and comprehension better than consuming information.
sources: Fiorella L. & Mayer R.E. (2016). Eight ways to promote generative learning. Educational Psychology Review 28(4) 717-741.
llm_prompt: Create a project brief for <age>-year old learners to create something original related to <task> in <duration> minutes. This could be a diagram, poster, model, story, or presentation that demonstrates mastery. Provide clear requirements and creative freedom.

Name: AdvancedOrganiser
Description: Brief overview to help students organize new information
explanation: This activity activates prior knowledge (long term memory) which increases the probability it can be activated later when needed (working memory). Organizers provide a conceptual scaffold for integrating new information.
sources: Luiten J. Ames W. & Ackerson G. (1980). A meta-analysis of the effects of advance organizers on learning and retention. American Educational Research Journal 17(2) 211-218.
llm_prompt: Create a visual organizer or concept map template for <task> suitable for <age>-year old learners. This should help them organize key concepts and see relationships before diving deeper. Keep it simple and clear for a <duration>-minute activity.

Name: Introduction
Description: Initial presentation introducing the lesson topic
explanation: Clear introductions establish learning objectives and activate schema. They help students understand the purpose and structure of the lesson reducing cognitive load during instruction.
sources: Sweller J. van MerriÃ«nboer J.J.G. & Paas F. (1998). Cognitive architecture and instructional design. Educational Psychology Review 10(3) 251-296.
llm_prompt: Write an engaging <duration>-minute introduction for <age>-year old learners about <task>. Include a hook to capture attention, clear learning objectives, and an overview of what they'll discover. Make it exciting and relevant to their lives.

Name: ExplainClass
Description: Teacher explains concepts with class-wide discussion
explanation: Interactive explanations with class discussion promote active engagement and allow immediate clarification of misconceptions. Dialogic teaching supports co-construction of knowledge.
sources: Alexander R.J. (2006). Towards Dialogic Teaching: Rethinking classroom talk. Dialogos.
llm_prompt: Create a small explanatory text about <task> for <age>-year old learners that will be used in a <duration>-minute class discussion. Include 3-4 thought-provoking questions to ask students during the explanation to encourage participation and check understanding.
